Literature Review:
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the production of autoantibodies and inflammation in multiple organs. The pathogenesis of SLE is complex and multifactorial, involving the interplay of autoreactive B cells, interferons, and other immune cells. Recent studies have shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying SLE, revealing a network of genetic and epigenetic alterations that contribute to disease pathogenesis.

Autoreactive B cells are central to SLE pathogenesis, producing autoantibodies against nuclear and cytoplasmic antigens (1). These autoantibodies can be directed against specific epitopes, such as double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) or histone proteins (2). The production of autoantibodies is influenced by the activity of B cell receptor (BCR) signaling pathways, which can be modulated by various factors, including interferons (3).

Interferons, particularly type I interferons (IFN-α/β), play a crucial role in SLE pathogenesis. They are produced by autoreactive B cells and other immune cells in response to the presence of nucleic acids, such as dsDNA or RNA (4). IFN-α/β can induce the expression of genes involved in immune responses, including those involved in the production of autoantibodies (5).

Recent studies have identified novel mutations in genes affecting intrinsic B cell activation or clearance of interferogenic nucleic acids (6). For example, mutations in the CD22 gene have been associated with increased susceptibility to SLE (7). Similarly, mutations in the APOBEC3 gene have been linked to the production of autoantibodies against dsDNA (8).

Mitochondria have emerged as relevant inducers and/or amplifiers of SLE pathogenesis. They can disrupt organelle integrity or compartmentalization, leading to the release of interferogenic nucleic acids (9). Mitochondrial dysfunction can also result in defective metabolism, leading to the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and other pro-inflammatory molecules (10).

A variety of classic and novel SLE autoantibody specificities have been found to recapitulate genetic alterations associated with monogenic lupus or to trigger interferogenic amplification loops (11). For example, autoantibodies against dsDNA have been associated with mutations in the TNFRSF1A gene (12). Similarly, autoantibodies against ribonucleoproteins have been linked to mutations in the RPL5 gene (13).

Atypical B cells and novel extrafollicular T helper cell subsets have been proposed to contribute to the generation of SLE autoantibodies (14). These cells can produce cytokines and chemokines that promote the activation and differentiation of autoreactive B cells (15).

In conclusion, recent studies have provided new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying SLE pathogenesis. The interplay of autoreactive B cells, interferons, and other immune cells, along with genetic and epigenetic alterations, contributes to the development of SLE. Further research is needed to understand the complex interactions between these factors and to develop personalized, rational approaches to therapy.
